course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Music Theory I: Introduction to Tonal Music
course.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of Western music theory with an emphasis on reading and writing musical notation, ear training, and analytical listening. Students will develop an understanding of how texture, harmony, rhythm, dynamics, melodic development, and other parameters interact to create music. Examples used in the class will be drawn mostly, but not exclusively, from classical repertoire. Although prior musical training will be helpful, there are no prerequisites for the course.
course.prerequisites: a passing letter grade in LANG 1401 OR LANG 1402 OR LANG 1403 OR LANG 1404 OR LANG 1002 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: CORE 2632, SISP 1709

reviews.author: clyak
reviews.comment_content:
Can just look at others' comments. Everything is cumulative so you have to understand content taught in week 1 to understand those in week 2, etc.

Friendly reminder: Only take this course if you had dailos to carry you or you have rich music background.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor has good English so you can understand what he's saying clearly. He teaches theories in lectures and provide links related to what he said after class attached in the homework assignments. As long as you read those links (which takes around 15-30 mins) you can finish the assignments. The TAs are quite helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final: 25%
Midterm: 20%
Homework: 15%
Concert Report: 15%
Final Project: 10%
Attendance/Participation: 15%

Only marks for midterm and homework are released.
Didn't know if this course is absolute graded or not.

Midterm: 103/116 (High 116, mean 90, low 32)
Homework around 95-98%
Attendance full
*If you hand in your homework late, you will get 3 marks deducted.

My grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely HUGE WORKLOAD if you don't have a rich music background.

Attendance is taken by signatures previously but after midterm it is taken through iprs. So if you can't arrive shaw by 9:00 am sharp or you're not a morning person, don't take this course. Attendance accounts for 15%.

Final and midterm is quite easy if you know how to do the homework.The difficult part as everyone mentions, is ear training.
Most students in this course had music background and some are even composition students.

A bit about my background:
I took my music theory exam like 10 years ago and absolutely forgot everything. I play viola so I can't read the music written in G clef and F clef as fluently as everyone does so I struggled VERY MUCH during the first three lectures. Basically, I only had very limited music background (almost =0)

I spent at least 2 hours every week (1 hour after each lecture) to revise plus finishing my homework and I had a great friend who helped me A LOT (includ. explaining the concepts and teaching me how to do the homework) to get this grade. Great workload I would say.

For the music composition (final project), my work was so bad that it was taken as an example in class to teach the students but the instructor gives really detailed comments and explanations on what to improve.

No examples are given for the final report so I just literally searched online for references. The instructor just gave 3-4 sentences as examples which are quite vague and minimum word count is 350. Spent me 3 hours to do this as I had no idea what to write about so I just started making things up to reach the minimum word count.

reviews.author: Just nobody
reviews.title: Kind of an easy course (on one condition)
reviews.comment_content:
Probably the other reviews talked about this, so I will just skip it.
Although HUMA 2104 is for students that have no music background, I strongly recommend you to do a little pre-study if you donâ€™t really have some music background (At least know what is a note and rhythm). Because people with music background also take this course, making midterm mean higher than you imagine.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kaila is a very good instructor, he is really willing to answer your questions. Like, I have some questions about the final project, he gives me some really good advice. Also, he adds a lot of interaction in the class.
TA (Rod) is also very nice. During the tutorial, he will do some ear training and homework review with us, and if a student answered wrong, he will guide you step-by-step to answer the question correctly, as well as Kaila.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam 25%
Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Concert report 15%
Final Project 10%
Attendance/participation 15%

Midterm covers content from topic 1~7
Final covers content throughout the whole semester
Homework are just some 1 to 2 page(s) worksheet that wonâ€™t take really long to do (can be short like 15 mins, but can be long like an hour or two), but generally are very easy (for students with music background)
Concert report requires you to listen to a piece or a concert then analyse it from different perspectives, Kaila will talk about this when towards the end of semester.
Final project needs you to compose a 24 bars music, but parts of the assignment will be used for this final project, they will ask you to compose rhythms and melodies. Advices from TAs and Kaila will be given.
Attendance is the MOST important part IMO, because it is the easiest thing to do to get marks. Kaila will use iPRS or pen and paper to mark attendance, right when the class starts (so make sure you can attend EVERY lesson and make there on time)

Some stats:
Midterm mean: 90.36/116
reviews.comment_workload:
1 to 2 assignments per week, but as mentioned, they are generally easy (and again, for students with music background).
The workload is fine for me, and I recommend to do some ear training yourself, because the ones done in the tutorial is definitely not enough, and they can really help for your midterm and final

reviews.author: ctt062
reviews.comment_content: HUMA 1102 is an introduction to the history of Western art music, from the medieval era to the present day, with an emphasis on the period between Late Middle Ages (14th century) and Romanticism (19th century). Using the last half a millennium of repertoire as its primary point of reference, the course aims to change the way the student hears and understands music. We will explore the foundations of music cognition and acoustics, look at works in their historical and political context, inspect the relationship of music to other art forms, learn analytical listening skills, and try to understand the creative operations and craftsmanship behind music-making. Prior knowledge of music or music theory is not required, and some basics of notation are covered in class.
reviews.comment_teaching: professional teachers for students that have grade 5 or above music theory.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes on reading assignments 25%
Cumulative mid- and end-of-semester quiz 25% (12.5% each) Term paper (concert report) 35%
Attendance & participation 15%
reviews.comment_workload: 1 homework per week, the workload is very low

reviews.comment_content:
The basics of Western music theory with an emphasis on
analytical listening and rudimentary composing
reviews.comment_teaching: Kaila explains theory very clearly and he is not dull so you won't fall asleep quickly. The TA is also very nice and patient, you can really feel that he is trying hard to make sure everyone can catch up with the progress. You'll also get detailed comments after submitting every assignment so you can know how to make improvements.

Attendance/participation 15%

If you don't have any knowledge about music, you may need to put more time into it but overall it's not very hard to get good grades.

reviews.author: RyanTai
reviews.title: Review on HUMA 2104
reviews.comment_content:
The course is named music theory I, introduction to tonal music. In this course, students could learn about classic music theories. Apart from knowledge taught in class, students must attend at least two concerts/ workshops in Sep and Oct. At last, students have to compose a piece by themselves.

In the tutorials, the TA Mr. Galison will revise what the professor taught in the last few lessons, and provide interactive practices, like singing, hearing chords, and ear training about music types.

The course teaches about the things I learned while learning piano, so it was easy for me to handle. But I think it will be challenging for beginners with zero musical background to follow the lectures because it requires an understanding of music theory. For reference, I'm a pianist with ABRSM grade 8 and practicing piano for over 12 years.

Topic 1: Rhythm notation
Topic 2: Pitch notation
Topic 3: Keys and  scales
Topic 4: Intervals
Topic 5: Major key melodies
Topic 6: Triads and seventh chords
Topic 7: Minor key melody
Topic 8: Harmonic analysis
Topic 9: Rhythmic composition
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr. Kaila is really a passionate teacher, he uses the appropriate way to let students easily understand the words that came out of his mouth. He often shared his past experience and tried to make the lecture fun and interesting. Both Mr. Kaila and Galison are always willing to answer your questions and provide opinions about your assignments.

Every lecture only lasts for 50mins, which is desirable and won't be too long for us, so students won't be bored and fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: Mostly 90-95%, except for one due to late submission (-10%)
Midterm: 107/111
Canvas didn't create the grade for the final so I don't know about my score
Grading: A

Again, I strongly recommend those who wanted to take this course to THINK CAREFULLY before they register because Mr. Kaila taught at a fast pace, and beginners will find it hard to catch up with the progress. (from my perspective) Around 40-50% of the class have musical backgrounds and experience, so you have to work very hard to obtain a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lectures are held on Monday and Wednesday, so the professor will assign homework which will due before the next lesson. This means that the homework assigned after the class on Monday will due before the lecture on Wednesday, so students will be doing around 2 assignments each week.

The workload is heavy for me, especially writing the report for the concerts and composing 1-2 weeks before the final exam.

reviews.author: t.w_adrian
reviews.title: An introductory course to music theory for all
reviews.comment_content: This course is an introductory course to tonal music theory. Topics discussed in class vary from basic music knowledge such as rhythm and pitch notation to advanced concepts such as seventh chords and harmonic analysis. Students would be able to produce their own music composition at the end of the course. Even students with zero music background can understand the course content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Kaila is a lecturer full of passion in music and teaching. Students are thoroughly entertained in class throughout the semester. He often uses examples to simplify and explain music ideas and concepts that might be difficult to grasp in the beginning. The TA, Galison, is also helpful in coordinating the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam 25%
Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Concert report 15%
Final Project 10%
Attendance/ participation 15%

Midterm score: 111/111
Final grade: A+

The grading is lenient as I have skipped some classes and forgot to submit a few homework.

The mid term and final exams are straight-forward enough that one can do very well if they listen in class or read the reading materials provided after every class.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload could be a bit heavy to students. There are 1-to-2-paged homework assignments after every topic discussed in class. However, they are simple and just require 10 to 15 minutes to complete.

The main part of the course is to compose your own piano piece in the A-B-A format. The work is separated into several sub-parts and you would receive feedback from the instructor or the TA and have chances to improve your work.

Students are also required to attend concerts during the Cosmopolis Festival and write a concert report at the end of the term. There are clear guidance provided on writing the essay.

reviews.author: Dicky123
reviews.title: Casual and light hearted course!
reviews.comment_content: This course is an introductory course of music, I have no music background but I do love music. And its great to have a music course in ust without paying extra cost!!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor demonstrates concepts of music in a vivid way, like playing piano, using fun metaphors like fishballs and snowmans to illustrates the concepts of rhythms. It is pretty fun to me!
There are also some youtube video sharing to enrich our knowledge before and after class!
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade course! As always, huma courses are good grading!! :)

No attendance needed!
reviews.comment_workload: There is a mid term and some assignment, but if you pay attention in class, have some passion in music. I am sure you will do well!

    parallel keys
Topics 3 & 5. Discussion on studentsâ€™ rhythm composition

Good
-Good English accents
-provide a detailed explanation

Bad

-even though the prof provides a detailed explanation, it just meets 70% of the assignment, you need self- learning

24/3 update
starting from now, apart from hearing training, you will be trained for hearing the MELODY too, which is the aural part of the ABRSM practical exam. (sadly I failed my aural part in my practical exam)

hmm...I got 2 out of 30 marks in melody dictation, I guess it has no way to improve your absolute pitch in a short time. If you do not have the ability to write down the melody you listened to, try to get more marks in other parts.

21/3 Midterm
Let me update the information about the midterm :
1 hour to complete the test+ submission
the rhythm dictation will be repeated about 8 times, which may be enough for most of the students.
To be honest, it is very rush and you cannot finish if you are not familiar with the content (That's me, crying emoji.jpg)

Midterm results release:
Low 38/111
mean: 91.7/111
High: 111/111

9/6 Grade release
Letter grade: A-
Honestly speaking, a fair grade is given

My situation for reference:
-ABRSM grade 5 music theory 90+
-Mid-term and final are higher than the mean by 10 marks
-Spend around 3 hours per week on this course (excluding the class time)
-Marks of assignments are higher than mean
-Results of the final projects are unknown, but I guess I did well on them.

If you have a passion for music and learned grade 5 music theory before, you can try. If not, RUN!!
reviews.comment_workload:
almost 2 assignments per week
~1 hour per assignment

Warning!!!
From what I have typed in my title,
If you miss > one thing, please don't enroll in this course
Why?
Before I started to join the class, I think I am the lucky one as I have learned piano for several years and passed grade 5 music theory.

The fact is this is far not enough to meet this course!
Many students in this course have passed grade 5 music theory too, and also with absolute pitch & music sense.
You need to know what is the exact note that the piano played and a good musical sense so you can avoid many careless mistakes in your assignment. What the prof&ta teach in the class is FAR NOT ENOUGH.

Let me explain what is music sense with examples :
(i) In one of my assignments, I forget to add a few natural signs (â™®) in the same bar when I am doing a chromatic notes exercise.

(ii) I got 70+ marks in the last two assignments.......just because I do not write down the two horizontal lines for the roman numeral 5.


For people who are familiar with music systems, those are just common sense and this kind of mistake should not appear. It is what this course looks for and they will not remind you about this, they expect you to know about this after they introduce the topic.

Tips: better to check your answers via google (Eg. find something like chord calculator, interval calculator, etc) before submission, it is too easy to make mistakes when doing the assignment.

reviews.author: randomhuman
reviews.comment_content:
The content isn't as scary as others described. Basic theory background would surely have an advantage, but I think it's not impossible to catch up if you have no musical / theory background.

Lectures:
Week 1:
Introduction to the course, musical perception: music and time, overtone series

Week 2:
Pitch notation: staves and the grand staff, clefs;  accidentals, enharmonics; diatonic and chromatic half steps and whole steps.
Ear training on half and whole steps; rhythmic notation; note values; meter; bar lines; tempo; upbeats and downbeats; rests

Week 3:
Dotted and tied rhythms; tupelos; pick-up measures; rests; triple and duple meters
Rhythm, composition; musicianship exercises with rhythms; introducing keys and scales

Week 4:
Circle of fifths and keys, placement of accidentals
Devices for determining keys; circle of fifths in minor; minor scale forms (natural, harmonic, melodic); discussing rhythm composition exercise

Weel 5:
Ear training with major and minor keys and scales; relative and parallel keys
Intervals: numbers and qualities; textures in music: homophonic, polyphonic, monophonic

Week 6:
Motives and theme; writing melodies in major
Discussion on melodies in major, ear training with intervals

Week 7:
Introducing exercise for writing melodies in minor; more on intervals; review for midterm

Week 8:
Introduction of triads in major keys
Discussion on melodies in minor key; more on guidelines for concert report

Week 9:
Seventh chords; inversion of chords and figured bass; ear training with triads
Harmonic analysis in major; ear training with seventh chords

Week 10:
Chords in minor keys
More on harmonic analysis and modulation

Week 11:
Chord inversions and cadences

Week 12:
More on cadences; ear training with cadences
Introducing composition exercise (final project)

Week 13:
Analysing music examples from repertoire
Discussion of composition exercise

Weel 14:
Review for final exam
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture powerpoints are quite useful when it comes to revision. The tutorials are great, Rod tries very hard to attend to all his students' needs, and he's very helpful and nice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam: 25%
Midterm: 20%
Assignment: 15%
Final Project: 15%
Attendance: 15%
Concert Report: 10%

My grade: ~91%, A-
reviews.comment_workload: There is a piece of assignment after each lecture, but it's usually simple. There also is a concert report and a final composition project, taking up 10% and 15% of the final grade respectively.

reviews.author: lhtam
reviews.title: Great aural skill is also required
reviews.comment_content:
See attached file.

In tutorial, we will have melodic dictation, triad, seventh chord and cadence identification by ear practice, which also weighs heavily in final exam. People with perfect pitch is an advantage. If not like me, just do more practice (resources are provided in handouts) will be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is willing to answer question anytime. He also gives concrete comments on your composition project and concert report.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Final Exam - 25%
Online Midterm - 20%
Homework - 15%
Recording/Concert Report - 10%
Final Project - 15%
Attendance/participation - 15%

My result:
Online Final Exam - 21.26 / 25
Online Midterm - 15.92 / 20
Homework - 14.4 / 15
Recording/Concert Report - 9.5 / 10
Final Project - 13.65 / 15
Attendance/participation - 15 / 15
Overall: Around 89%

Final grade: A-

I think the professor modified the grading system as 89% will only get me a B+ according to the absolute grading table provided in previous comment. The course mean should be around 82 - 83%.

I would say having sound musical background is definitely an advantage. I did grade 5 ABRSM music theory a long time ago and pursuing performance diploma but still found very competitive in this course. So only take this if you are willing to devote much time and effort.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite large compare to other common core course. There are 2 homework to be submitted before lectures each week. You have to do it very carefully as most student will get almost full marks.

Also, you have to attend a concert from the Cosmopolis Festival and write a concert report this year as the pandemic improved.

The composition project is fine. He will guide you throughout the semester so basically you have plenty of time to modify.

reviews.author: Hilda C
reviews.comment_content:
It covers the syllabus of ABRSM grade 5.
Topic 1: Rhythm Notation
Topic 2: Pitch Notation
Topic 3: Rhythm Phrase Composition
Topic 4: Keys and scales
Topic 5: Intervals
Topic 6: Triads and chords
Topic 7: Analytic Listening
Topic 8: Major key melody
Topic 9: Minor key melody
Topic 10: Cadences
It is not difficult for students who have musical background. But for those who are totally new to musical theory, it will be hard and will need much time to catch up with the progress.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For the teaching materials, the professor does not provide any notes or ppt. in some of the topics, there are only some URL links for you to review the content.
For the teaching quality, the professor is quite clear when explaining the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final exam: 25%
Midterm: 20%
Homework: 15%
Concert report: 15%
Final project: 10%
Attendance/Participation: 15%
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is high.
There is a homework after each lecture and it has to be done before next lecture. Also, the deadline of both the concert report and final composition is exactly the day of final exam.

reviews.author: hyunsuparkk
reviews.title: review
reviews.comment_content: Up to and including Grade 5 in ABRSM Music Theory exams. Basic knowledge and giving you backgrounds in musical theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: Best instructors I had in this term. He was so easy to reach whenever I had questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, no stats gave. Attendance is mandatory.

I did around average with the assignments and 50% with the final exam and it was B-
reviews.comment_workload: Don't take this course unless you're ready to not only learn the mechanisms but also to regularly practice your ear. The final exam and midterm had a dictation part.

reviews.comment_content: Up to and including Grade 5 in ABRSM Music Theory exams.

reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, no stats given. Attendance is mandatory.

I did around average with the assignments and 50% with the final exam and it was B-
reviews.comment_workload: Don't take this course unless you're ready to not only learn the mechanisms but also to regularly practice your ear. Final exam and midterm had a dictation part.

reviews.author: heyhihere
reviews.comment_content:
I would say, the content of this course is quite easy if you have some musical background.
Content:
Rhythm notation
Pitch notation
Key and scales
Harmonic analysis (cadence)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Kaila speaks good and fluent English.
He is nice and is willing to answer any question you ask.
He may even give advice for your composing project if you ask for it. (though I didn't)
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading
This course counts attendance though
I get 3-4 marks above mean in the assignments, mid-term and final. I even submitted my final project late (which deducts marks severely)
I dont think I did the writing task (which is originally a concert report) well, but I finally get B+ and I didnt expect it.
reviews.comment_workload:
You need to complete assignments after class. I dont think those assignments are difficult.
There is a mid-term and final exam but it is not difficult. Just pay attention in class is enough for it.
There is a writing task. The requirement for it is not strict, but you have to pay efforts in it. Let the professor know how hardworking you are!!!

reviews.author: jc2048
reviews.title: A great course for people with intermediate music knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly about basic to intermediate music theory. Most of HK students should have learnt the simplest part of the theory, but this course will be more difficult.

The content is mostly within the range of ABRSM grade 5 music theory. If you have had the exam, then you can skip 80% of the contents.

Content of the course:
- Rhythmic/Pitch Notations (Things that you saw in a music book)
- Keys and scales
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Until here are the stuff that most of the people have learnt in secondary school

- Intervals & Chords
- Major & Minor key melody
- Harmonic analysis (Cadences)
- Some listening and ear training for identifying chords

For those who only have MINIMAL KNOWLEDGE on music:
THIS IS NOT AN EASY COURSE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ilari is quite nice and speaks English fluently (unlike some of the professors).

Some of the lectures I just join the Zoom meeting, open the camera, then continue to work on other stuff and listen what he says occasionally. In my opinion, he explains stuff quite clearly. I don't know if it is because I have a musical background or not.
He also stay in the Zoom meeting after the class to answer your questions.
Also, this course requires to turn on the Zoom camera, and he will randomly pick students to answer his questions, so make sure you know what is he talking
about when you do other stuff in the class. By the way, just don't do other stuff.

Tutorial is basically useless in my opinion, and this is my only feeling after attending the first tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
Here are the original grading for the course:
Midterm (19% / 20%)
Final (23.5% / 25%)
Homework (about 12-13% / 15%)
Concert report ( - / 15%) > CANCELLED, become listening assignment
Final Project ( - / 10%)
Attendance/participation ( - / 15%, I attended most of the lectures)

Overall: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
There are about 1 assignment per week, which takes me about 15-30 minutes to finish, base on the contents of the assignment. Most of them are just drawing and identifying chords, or filling melodic phrases.
2 of the assignments required you to compose a 8-bar melodic phrase, which can be used for the final project. These 2 assignment took me a longer time to complete, about 45-60 minutes.

Midterm and Final are easy because 85% of the questions are similar to assignments, and with about 15% listening tasks. So if you can complete the assignments by yourself, there will be no problem to get high mark in midterm and final.

The final project is composing a ABA structured 24 bar melody with harmonization. This takes me about 5-6 hours to finish which is not a lot considering this is 10% of the total grade. The abovementioned assignments will guide you the process, also professor spent 2-3 lessons talking about composition so that should be easy.

The listening assignment is a replacement for the cancelled concert report. A piece is randomly chosen, you have to listen it and then write a 500 word report, which is not very difficult.

reviews.author: Joanna6
reviews.comment_content:
The content is super easy for the first 2 or 3 classes, but the difficulty of the course increases 'exponentially'. Though that was being said, professor will provide many sources for you. You can gain a more thorough understanding by going through them.
It would be better if you have some musical background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is really passionate in teaching. He is very willing to answer questions in and after class. He also replies email very quickly.
He often asks questions in class and randomly pick students to answer. So it forces you to concentrate in class.
It's totally fine if you don't know how to answer the questions as he will guide you step by step to find the answer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Competition is fierce cuz basically most of the classmates have musical background. The mean for assignments and exams are very high as well.
Final Exam25%
Midterm20%
Homework15%
Concert report15%
Final Project10%
Attendance/participation15%
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is appropriate.
one assignment per week (as the course becomes more and more difficult, you might want to do more practice with the sources provided by the professor)
midterm (the midterm is slightly more difficult than the homework, it would be better to spend 3 to 4 days to revise)
final project: you have to compose a melody in ABA form and harmonize one of the sections.
term paper ~ concert report: we can't go to concert this year due to covid, so professor assigned pieces for us to analyse.
Final: the difficulty is similar to midterm but it involves more ear training questions, so it would better to spend more time revising.

reviews.author: peterho0709
reviews.comment_content: easy to handle if you have passed ABRSM grade 5 music theory
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor is very nice and kind, always answer your questions  after lecture
reviews.comment_grading: all classmates are strong, the mean of the assignments are usually above 90% since most students choose this course because they usually have some musical background
reviews.comment_workload:
1 assignment per lecture, but not too difficult to finish.
There is a composition project which requires you to finish a major and minor melody with chords adding to it. There is also an essay for you to work on a concert and analyse the music pieces using knowledge that you have learnt during lecture.

reviews.author: Michael Chan333
reviews.comment_content: The contents are basically ABRSM grade 5 theory plus some seventh chords. If u have never studied music before , I don't recommend taking this course. The content might be too much for u . One semester of it cover years of theory knowledge. Teacher will also discuss famous classical piece with u .That discussion is the most valuable. U will also be taught to feel the music and learn to appreciate classical music.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is very enthusiastic about teaching. He doesn't mind staying after class to answer silly questions. More importantly , he teaches u how to feel and appreciate music more than just learning the  theory by memory ( lots of music teacher do that !)Just be brave and ask him questions if u have any enquiry. He is very nice and enjoy interaction.
reviews.comment_grading: I believe the grading is quite nice. The midterm and hw questions are not difficult.i will provide my grade after I receive it.
reviews.comment_workload: U have to hand in one hw every week. The questions are not difficult but u might have to search for more resources in order to fully understand because a lot of content is covered in a short time . Overall , the workload is okay .

reviews.author: SATB
reviews.title: An interesting course.
reviews.comment_content: The contents are rather basic. If you have a little music background, I think you will have no difficulties in understanding the concepts. If you have already taken the ABRSM grade 8 theory exam, you will certainly ace this course. If that is the case, I think you should consider taking HUMA 3104 (Music Theory II) instead.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Kaila's enthusiasm in music can be felt very easily. I like the way he teaches, he explains the concepts very clearly. He always uses the piano and sings to help us understand the contents, and uses some repertoires (Like compositions by J. S. Bach and Mozart) as examples.  

Attendance and participation are included in the course's grade. So make sure to actively participate in class, answer questions from the professor, and turn on your webcam (If the class is online), in order to get all the points in terms of attendance and participation.

The TA, Rod, is a nice guy. In tutorials, he gives us rhythmic dictations, asks us to read the rhythm out, etc. Those are good practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course uses ABSOLUTE grading.

Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Listening Assignment 15%
Final Project 10%

Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: At least one piece of homework assignment per week, but most of them can be completed within half an hour. Some composition exercises may take longer. For the composition exercises, it is always good to send the draft to Prof. Kaila to ask for his opinion. He will provide an in-depth comment on your work. You can really learn a lot if you talk to him.

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: è­¦ä¸–: Only register if you have good musical sense and music theory background
reviews.comment_content:
*Note that my grading for this course is based on my subjective thoughts. I'm a DSE music student so this review may not be the best indicator to gauge whether the course is suitable for you if you're a newbie to music theory.*

The content basically covers ALL ABRSM music theory content, from grade 1 to 6. Others have already copy and pasted the syllabus on their reviews so perhaps I won't do it here.

The content itself is quite straight-forward for students to learn: ranging from basic rhythm patterns, key signatures, scales to intervals, melodic patterns and texture. But then after mid-term, it goes south. It contains a bunch of triads and 7th chords, which is crazy for an introductory class for music theory. That's why you shouldn't reg this course if you haven't studied 5/8th grade theory.

PS. If you want to consolidate the contents learned in class, be sure to purchase ABRSM's music theory practices to do. I'm sure those helps a lot. Online resources are also helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I fucking LOVE Ilari.

Ilari is a music enthusiast and humorous guy. He's very experienced in music and you can simply search him on google as to listen to his composition. He also gives us so much flexibility for projects, e.g. allowing you to switch music piece for listening assignment if you don't like it; He allows you to ask him about homework and will guide you on the right path (he gives very detailed feedback and never 'hea' me when I have concerns). I really hope that professors in UST can be like him. Bonus mark: he is a hong kong lover (if you know, you know. wink wink)

Regarding Rod, the tutor, the content has much to be desired. He is quite a nice guy to talk with, but the content in tutorials are quite subpar and monotonous, e.g. rhythmic dictation. Also, he always makes mistakes and is quite inefficient. More importantly, he is very rigid in marking assignments, e.g. you have to write PERFECT authentic cadence to earn a mark, A note does not equal Bbb because it is different... what he does is kind of like é›è›‹è£æŒ‘éª¨é ­

As my title implies, if you have learnt theory before, you'll have a great time attending class and answering professor's questions (Attendance is needed. He picks students to answer questions, so never æ›æ©Ÿ). But if you're a beginner, then you're going to suffer miserably -- Learning triads, melodic and rhythmic phrases after merely three month of introductions... Simply put, it would be overwhelming, if not extremely difficult, for people who are new learners. What is most important is that Ilari is not exam-oriented, meaning, he won't teach you the skills of theory. That's why I strongly recommend you to buy Eric Taylor's ABRSM theory exercises, or go online to search for materials for self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got A+ eventually. Details of grading is not given, but as far as i'm concerned, you have to reach at least 96-97% to get an A+.

Final 24/25
midterm 20/20
homework 14/15
listening assignment 15/15 (concert report was cancelled)
final project 10/10
attendance 15/15

Just so you know, assignment and final project's scores are not announced, but Ilari mentioned it to me in an email because he realised that there are some mistakes in my grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
No e-book is needed (there are digital handouts, those aren't really helpful though), and there is at least one assignment each week. The workload for each of the assignments depends: For those with intervals and scales, there are definite answers. But for assignments about composition, e.g. 8-bar melodic phrases, it will cost more time, perhaps 1-2 hours to finish. I suggest you contact prof to have some feedback before handing in your final work, as to ensure that you can have a clear idea of what your marks will be for the assignment. I think this is great because many professors simply don't give a f to their students and hea reply emails, whereas Ilari is willing to discuss with you in a detailed manner,.

Although there are homework assignments every week, it isn't necessarily a bad thing -- As homework accounts for 15% of grading, even if you lose some marks in particular assignments, it won't affect much on the overall grade due to small proportions. It is also a great way to consolidate concepts, so it's fine to me.

I think the workload is moderate because I have learnt all of the topics before from ABRSM syllabus. But if you are a beginner, you should surely think twice before choosing this course.

If you got any questions or want me to help you out, feel free to comment below :)

reviews.author: Hollow
reviews.title: Not recommend to take if you have zero musical backgroud
reviews.comment_content: Basically it's stuff around ABRSM grade 5 to grade 8 music theory. It's easy for you to pick up the course content if you have some music knowledge in advance. The listening part would not be hard if you have great ears, it's about rythms, chords and cadences.
reviews.comment_teaching: Some said Professor Page reads the lecture notes word for word, well I won't deny it but he is quite a nice guy and he is willing to answer students' question during or after the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam 25%
Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Recording/ Concert Report 10%
Final Project 15%
Attendace 15%

If the class is held online, you have to turn your cam on in order to have your attendace taken.

There is a singing part in the midterm which you'll have to record it yourself, I believe it's fine if you are not a complete tone deaf.

The grading is kinda generous though, I got an A- at the end even I've made a lot of mistakes in homework and exams.

The course would be easy for you if you are musically trained, but for those who are not, I believe you will be competent with those studefnts as well if you are willing to work hard enough. So good luck taking the course :)
reviews.comment_workload: I have to admit that it is not easy to have two assignments every week. The homework basically comprises of repetitve and strenous work which students with deep musical knowledge may find it boring, but going through them really helps giving a solid foundation of the concepts taught in class if you have little to no musical knowledge prior to the course.

reviews.author: Jackal
reviews.title: Only take if you have interest in music and the work ethic
reviews.comment_content: I have attached the syllabus so I won't go in depth. Basically if you already passed ABRSM grade 5 music theory, and have some ear training (so you have some sense of relative pitch and rhythm), I believe you can take this course, even if your music theory is kinda rusty. However, the workload is really high, as you can see from the grading and other reviews probably. I have attached the first 3 homework I got, it gets much more complex later. If you're rusty in music theory like I was, you'll have to spend a bit of time studying the material, especially when it gets to the triads and cadences part. Keep in mind you have to juggle this with your other courses too. long story short is if you think you can just chill and get an easy grade, don't take this course, well unless you're some sort of musical genius I guess.
reviews.comment_teaching: Your typical standard teaching, pretty boring if you ask me, it is pretty funny watching him mess up sometimes though. Keep in mind you are forced to participate like answering the questions in lectures as it is part of your grade, which kinda sucks.
reviews.comment_grading:

reviews.comment_workload: I think the other reviews speak for themselves lol

reviews.author: MoSorWaiLa
reviews.title: Don't pick it unless you have a very strong music sense
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to the attachment.
It mainly talks about the basics of music theory, ranging from pitch notation to cadences. You will learn the theory stuff during the lectures and do ear training in the tutorials.
I find the reviews commenting that you need to have music background and reach at least ABRSM 8 grade of music theory.  However, I think the most important thing is you need to have a pair of great ear, pitch perfect and the innate music sense before you decide to take the course. Otherwise, you will feel very painful if you cannot identify intervals, chords and cadences. In the exam, you need to distinguish all of them and such part weighs a lot of marks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think he has killed my interest in music. He simply reads the words from the power point and gives us lots of assignments to enhance. In the ear training part, he just shows us how the chords/ intervals are performed once and ask us to identify them all which is quite impossible for students without music backgrounds.
Also, the teaching progress is too fast as there is a whole new chapter every lesson. Therefore, if you are unable to recognize the notes beforehand, you will hardly be able to catch up.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Final Exam25%
Online Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Recording/Concert Report 10%
Final Project 15%
Attendance/participation 15%

The final project is a piano composition exercise. I think it is too difficult and unfair for students who don't have a piano at home.
reviews.comment_workload: You know, we are at Hong Kong University of Stress and Tension. You are not supposed to only focus on one course or one common core throughout your hectic semester. For Timothy's course, you need to hand in one assignment BEFORE EACH  LESSON while you need to work hard on other courses. And the homework are sometimes quite complicated.  And if you are not good at music and are not considering music in your future prospect, it is too time-consuming for you to devote so much effort in this course.

reviews.comment_grading: Not bad I think. I donâ€™t think I did a very good job but a A- is decent enough for my homework and midterm and my free writing essay lol.

reviews.comment_content:
Grade 5 Music theory

Everything from the basics:
Pitches, rhythm, scales, major scales, minor scales, intervals, motives, melodies, writing melodies, triads, chords, inversions, cadences.

you will just need to bring a pencil and paper for the class as it is quite classical.

reviews.author: Hogcryat
reviews.title: Challenging but interesting
reviews.comment_content:
Separated into theory and pratical. Overall the course was challenging, speaking from a person that has little music background.

The theories were interesting, but that's probably because I am interested to know more in the first place. For people not interested, this course is not only tough, but also boring.

The practical was very challenging, most notably, distinguishing chords from hearing them, given there are so many inversions that might be similar in sound.

Personally really enjoyed the Intimacy of Creativity part of the course. It is a program where you can interact with some world famous or upcoming contemporary music composers. Again this was spoken from a person that is interested in music in the first place.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very clear explanations during lectures. Demonstrations were very frequent as well.

Note that they only teach until the point where you can memorise or undstant a tiny fraction of the theories, probably due to time constraints. To understand the theories inside and out, you have to rely on outside resources.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, to get A you need 90%. Overall a tough grading system.
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively heavy workload.

Assignments are very frequent, probably twice a week. But they are probably very easy for people with music background, but they were time consuming for me.

Tutorials and lectures both take attendance randomly, which means you are restricted by their schedule.

reviews.author: Lia
reviews.comment_content:
Course content similar to ABRSM grade 5 music theory

If you have no music background: Think clearly before taking the course as nearly all people in class have some music background.

If you have passed grade 5 theory: You can learn more than ABSRM syllabus

If you have passed grade 8 theory: this is a easy course to deal with

reviews.author: chunyinhello
reviews.comment_content: Most of the content are really useful if you are interested in studying music.  The content starts from easy stuff, like keys and rhythm and would start to get really difficult after the mid-term exam with chords and sevenths. Tutorial classes are required for the course and mainly helps students practice for the dictation parts in the mid-term and final exam. It would be easy for students that have played an instrument before or has other music backgrounds. However, it would be very difficult for students that do not have any background in music, especially for the dictation part, where students are required to identify the chords and sevenths. A textbook is required to be bought online for around $400.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, paying attention in class really isn't essential. You can read the powerpoint slides later or just read the required book to learn about the content. However, if you are interested in music, you would enjoy the teaching as the lecturer would share a lot of different music pieces as examples in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is based on absolute grading.
A+: 97â€“100%   A: 93â€“96.99%   A-: 90 â€“92.99%
B+: 87â€“89.99%   B: 83â€“86.99%   B-: 80â€“82.99%
C+: 77â€“79.99%   C: 73â€“76.99%   C-: 70â€“72.99%
D: 60â€“69.99%   F: 0 â€“59.99%
Final Exam 25%; Midterm 20%; Homework 15%; Concert report 15%; Final Project 10%; Attendance 15%
The final exam is cumulative from the mid-term exam (includes all content learnt in the whole semester). Both exams include a written exam and a dictation. I believe it would not be too difficult as long as you understand the content in the powerpoints for the written exam. However, the dictation part is extremely difficult for students that have never played any musical instruments. Even practicing would not be useful for the dictation if you do not have any music talent.
Students are required to attend 4 concerts (included in attendance) and write a report (an essay describing your experience) of around 600 words based on one of the concerts.
The final project is a composition that is required to hand in at the end of the semester. Previous assignments would help you finish the task piece by piece.
Attendance is randomly taken in classes, so I would suggest you to attend all of them to avoid losing marks.
To conclude, as long as you finish all the homework, concert report and final project on time, attend all classes and tutorial sessions, and understand the course content, I believe getting a B would not be too difficult. However, a strong music background or talent is definitely required for an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this course is terrible, possibly the worst in all courses. There are assignments in almost all lectures (twice a week). It would take around 2 hours to finish each assignment on average (varies depending on the content and whether you have any music background). If you do not want a busy semester, DO NOT CHOOSE THIS COURSE!!!

reviews.author: avv
reviews.title: Take this only if you're prepared for a high workload and have good musical background
reviews.comment_content: There's another recent review which has already covered this part well so I won't write much here. Just that there's a lot of musical theory content squeezed into one course. Despite what the course content says 'No musical background needed', it is highly recommended you know concepts before taking this class. Take this class if you REALLY, I mean really FUCKING want to learn some interesting music stuff like composition and analyzing melodies. This will be different from other HUMA classes which are more about memorizing lecture slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fantastic. Ilari is indeed passionate and explains clearly. He is a nice Finnish professor who is fluent in English. Even Galison the TA is quite good in his teaching and makes tutorials fun. The biggest downside of this class is there is strict attendance taken sharp at 9 am. If you even come 15 minutes late, you will lose out. But then the class itself is only 50 minutes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading can be pretty strict. Stuff like how major and minor chords are notated etc. Plus you really need to work with musical staff which is really hard  especially when there's little space to fill out notes.

Midterm was lengthy and had to be finished in 50 minutes. Final however time was adequate. And understand that there will be students who will have extensive musical background so be highly aware of the competition in class.

Pro Tip- The most challenging part of this class is the ear training. So from day 1, USE THIS WEBSITE TO TRAIN YOUR EARS. https://www.teoria.com/en/exercises/
Better to use this for about 5-10 mins a day rather cram towards the end.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is awfully high. There's a homework assigned every class and that could take an hour or so to finish. I guess this is the case since music theory is not something that can be memorized a few nights before the exam. Rather the concepts build up over one another. Initially it may be manageable, but not when you get busier in the semester and when the concepts start to get harder.

reviews.author: Finnick
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content: Intensive contents with identify different basic chords. Do not attempt this course if you are not familiar with theory stuffs. Teaching outline is pretty fast, it will be quite hard in listening to chords. It is quite impossible for beginning to catch up in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Best professor I have ever met. Passionated teaching  and required to students not to use any electronic devices. Unlike reading the powerpoint, Kaila never uses ppt in his teaching. The hardest thing is to attend 9am classes on time because attendance is counted at the beginning of the classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam 25%
Midterm 20%
Homework 15%
Concert report 15%
Final Project 10%
Attendance/participation 15%
reviews.comment_workload: Quiet heavy. At least one take-home assignment is given per week and submit it next lecture. Concert report and composition task is due near the final. Don't be deadline fighter for the concert report composition otherwise they make you crazy!

reviews.author: Erfan
reviews.title: Great Course, Funny Professor
reviews.comment_content:
If you have a background in music like playing the piano for a while, this should be a great fit for your level. If you've done AP music theory like me, this should be amazing revision as well as great for solidifying your foundation knowledge!

Weeks 1 ~ 3: The really basic stuff. Notation, rhythm, keys and scales etc. i.e. things you've probably learnt from primary / secondary school music classes.

Weeks 4 ~ 7: Melodies. Musical textures, composition structures, intervals.
Weeks 8 ~ 10: Chords. Triads and seventh chords in major and minor keys, inversions. This is where it starts to pick up the pace.
Weeks 11 ~ 13: Harmony. Chord progressions, cadences, harmonising a melody.
reviews.comment_teaching:
By far the best thing about the course. Professor Kaila is not only an amazing composer (you should definitely stalk his Shostakovitch in Context on Spotify), he's also a genuinely funny and easy going person.

He dives into more abstract topics of rhythm and pitch and notation in a way that's still interesting for someone who has previous background. He explains topics very clearly while playing the piano so you develop a better ear as well which really helps.

He genuinely spends hours and hours writing feedback for EACH person's composition. No, it's not just a single line, I got almost 4 detailed paragraphs which is basically an essay so it goes to show how much he cares for the student's improvement.

I might be a bit biased since he saw my interest in music composition and spent almost an hour after the lecture helping me with what I had and just giving me guidance and advice in general, but I guess that's good enough of a reason to say that he's a great professor.

Galison is the tutorial instructor who's there for every lecture as well as your extra tutorials. He's also amazing and lets you have a good laugh in his classes which really helps lighten up the mood, alongside helping you with any problems you might have, even in his spare time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading here so don't worry about the crazy mean and s.d.

-Mid-term (20%): I got a 110/120, mean 92/120 with s.d of around 27
-Finals (25%): I got a 194/218, mean 168 with s.d 37
-Final Composition (10%)
-Concert Report (15%)
-Homework (25%)
-Attendance (25%)

This is when things start going downhill. Half the class has a really solid classical background while the other half absolutely close to none, which is why you end up with a standard deviation of 30 in a 120 mark exam :) I absolutely do NOT recommend taking the course without being able to read notes fluently (and I mean FLUENTLY), unless you love music, then totally go ahead because you'll need lots of dedication. I only say this because of how much my friends with no musical background struggled, but they also loved the course despite their not being so great grades so go for it if you'd like!

Not all hope is lost though, since the grading is very split up. If you attend all lectures, do all the homework with care, write a decent concert report, as well as pay attention to professor Kaila's feedback on your composition, it should be good enough to get a decent B range!

LIFE TIP: If you're horrible at melodic dictation just like me, SKIP IT, and instead totally focus on writing down the rhythm of the piece only rather than the pitch! (This gets you 15/30 marks in that segment, and since the exam is 220 marks, losing 15 marks is absolutely nothing, you can easily score full marks on the other parts)

Remember to differentiate different 7th chords as well!
reviews.comment_workload:
I'd say that the workload is quite heavy. There is homework due every single lecture, as well as a concert report to write, as well as a composition.

This is I guess why homework is 25% of the grade so I'm not really complaining

reviews.author: PeterHo
reviews.title: Learning curve can be quite steep for non-musical-background students
reviews.comment_content:
Weeks 1 ~ 3: The really basic stuff. Notation, rhythm, keys and scales etc. i.e. things you've probably learnt from primary / secondary school music classes.
Weeks 4 ~ 7: Melodies. Musical textures, composition structures, intervals.
Weeks 8 ~ 10: Chords. Triads and seventh chords in major and minor keys, inversions. This is where it starts to pick up the pace.
Weeks 11 ~ 13: Harmony. Chord progressions, cadences, harmonising a melody.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Kaila is clearly very enthusiastic on the subject. He gives very structured explanation on the course materials. The lectures are generally easy to follow and do a very good job at stimulating interest in the theory itself.

Tutorial sessions mostly consist of ear training and melodic dictation (at the later stage). This is meant for you to familiarise how the things you learn in the lectures are applied in a musical setting and helps a lot with the composition exercise and exam.

Listening to Dr. Kaila chat with students with musical background is also great for clearing up anything you don't understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Homework 25%
Midterm 20%
Final Exam 25%
Concert report 15%
Attendance / participation 15%

Homework problems are fairly basic so if you attend the lectures you'll understand most of it and have no problem.

Midterm and final both consist of written and listening tasks. A small portion of content needs to be memorised (e.g. circle of fifths, interval names, chords). Also DO EAR TRAINING!!!

IPRS is used to take attendance at the start of lectures. Dr. Kaila will also occasionally pick students to answer questions during lectures. Tutorial sessions also require attendance.

Is a 09:30 a.m. course though so decide this for yourself.
reviews.comment_workload:
Somewhat heavy workload, but most of the time manageable.

Homework is usually in the form of print-out worksheets of the textbook. Pretty straightforward most of the time (e.g. identify / construct the interval / chord) but tends to get slightly repetitive because they're practically the same task.

Part of the homework is a composition exercise. It is procedural, i.e. you build it up as you learn. Dr. Kaila will provide most of the guidelines, the rest can be found in the textbook. Doesn't need to be a Bach-level masterpiece, just needs to show that you can utilise the knowledge you've learnt.

Concert report requires you to, obviously, attend a concert and write a short report (short in comparison to some essays in other CC courses). "Concerts" are not the pop music ones, but the more "classical" ones. Dr. Kaila will recommend you go to one hosted by HKUST with free admission.

Also need to do ear training off-course. Dr. Kaila will provide resource for practice. Being able to identify chords by listening is crucial to this course.

reviews.author: JacJacNguyen
reviews.comment_content: Basic music theory at the very beginning (about 2-3 weeks) and the topics become more difficult e.g. cadence (especially for the listening part) For people who do not have any background it might be quite hard after the mid-term
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching was well organized and was able to explain the theory clearly
The tutorial (taught by IA) mainly contained ear training and singing which were really useful
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 25%
Attendance 15%
Midterm 20%
Concert report 15%
Final Exam 25%

Attendance is very important because not only the lecture took attendance but also the tutorial.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot as he assigned homework nearly every week
You need to revise your composition if it does not meet the requirements so you should follow the rules in the textbook

reviews.author: Hannah
reviews.comment_content: Started with basic stuff of music theory to nearly grade 8 music theory level. Quite hard to catch up for ppl with no music background.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and organized. He is quite strict on attendence tho. Tutor is really nice!!
reviews.comment_grading: Average grading, only that the mean is usually quite high (there are students who are really good....). Exam is really difficult for the listening part. You have differetiate 7th chords and do a melodic dictation.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy. Got hw every lesson, tutorial every week, concert review, composition exercise. Tutorial is quite useful but also demanding. A lot of ear training exercises.

reviews.author: mhcm138
reviews.title: A very competitive common core
reviews.comment_content: The content covered most of the ABRSM Grade 1-5  and few Grade 6-8 music theory. They are mainly about pitches, key signatures, time signatures, scales, intervals, triads, seventh chords, modulation, cadences etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor was passionate and used piano to enhance his teaching. He was very nice and willing to answer your questions after the lectures. He may use students' composition to tell us what is good or bad. During his lecture, no electronic devices were allowed.

The tutorials were conducted by his TA, mainly focus on aural training (melodic dictation, rhythm dictation, distinguish the triads, chords and cadences) and pointed us the common mistakes in the homework. The training will help you to familiarize the format of the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 25%

The homework percentage is same as the final exam percentage, so it is very important to score full marks in every homework, this consequently will give you a big advantage towards your final grade. It is suggested that you can check the answers with your friends in the same course in order to make sure you didn't make careless mistakes. REMEMBER, DO NOT SUMMIT THE HOMEWORK LATE!!!! You will get 50% or 100% marks deduction on that piece of homework. I scored around 98% in total of all 16 homework assignments.

Final Exam 25%

There is no release of our own score or statistics. My competitors were very strong, many of them left the exam venue very early....I finished the exam 50 mins before time is up, but it is recommended to stay until the end and check your paper again and again.....æ­£æ‰€è¬‚å°å¿ƒé§›å¾—è¬å¹´èˆ¹

Concert report 15%

There was also no release of the mark of concert report. You need to attend one professional classical music concerts and write analysis on a piece or a movement in a symphony. It is suggested that the concert report can focus on the meter, tonality, dynamics changes, tempo changes, any cadences observed and modulations. It is great to describe the mood and your own feeling of the piece. I also give some basic background (history) of the piece. Moreover, I included my comments on the concertmaster and the soloists of that concert. Professor also focus on your language in the concert report.

Midterm 20%

The Mean is 96.78/120, SD:20.59
I scored around +0.6sd

Attendance/participation 15%

The TA Galison LAU used a crazy way to take the attendance. First, he used IPRS to check attendance, then used raffle system (by calling you to answer professor's questions) to make sure you are in the room, not your friends helping you to take attendance. I skipped one lecture because I woke up late..not sure how will it affect the attendance mark.

Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
For me, the homework workload is quite harsh.There are 16 assignments throughout the semester. You should expect that you may spend at least an hour in a piece of homework if you do it carefully. Moreover, some homework may have many questions and very tedious. For example, there are at least 50 questions in one page of triads, sevenths and intervals homework. The main problem is, a piece of homework is assigned on Monday's lecture and you must submit on Wednesday's lecture......

It is very lucky that professor allow us to submit the concert report and the final composition project on the day of final examination. However, you may need to spend some time on working them.

Before final examination, it is advised to use an online ear training website called teoria, the website can help you to practice on distinguishing between different triads and sevenths chords.
